qas.question: What do Slavic languages tend to do to their verbs?
What two grammatical aspects can verbs in Czech have?
In perfective verbs, what state is the action the verb describes in?
In which verbs in Czech is the action the verb describes still ongoing?
What describes the state of the action of the verb at the time specified by its tense?
What two types of time measurement are there?
What are time measurements part of?
When tense is specified what happens to the action?
How many main Slavic Languages are there?
What is similar about three tenses in Czech?

context: Typical of Slavic languages, Czech <a0_0>marks<a0_0/> its verbs for one of two grammatical aspects: <a1_0><b5_0>perfective and imperfective<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Most verbs are part of <b6_0>inflected aspect pairs<b6_0/>—for example, koupit (perfective) and kupovat (imperfective). Although the verbs' <b9_0>meaning<b9_0/> is similar, in perfective verbs the action is <a2_0><b7_0>completed<b7_0/><a2_0/> and in <a3_0>imperfective<a3_0/> verbs it is ongoing. This is distinct from past and present tense, and any Czech verb of either aspect can be conjugated into any of its <b8_0>three<b8_0/> tenses. <a4_0>Aspect<a4_0/> describes the state of the action at the time specified by the tense.
